revision.comment: Removing [[:c:File:2004-10-23-ASGeisler-byMGeisler.jpg|2004-10-23-ASGeisler-byMGeisler.jpg]], it has been deleted from Commons by [[:c:User:Christian Ferrer|Christian Ferrer]] because: per [[:c:Commons:Deletion requests/File:2004-10-23-ASGeisler-byMGeisle
revision.text:
'''Alan Stark Geisler''' (September 30, 1931 – January 6, 2009) was an American [[food chemist]], best known for creating the [[red onion]] [[sauce]] most often used as a [[condiment]] topping on [[hot dog]]s in [[New York City]].<ref name=RecordObit>Levin, Jay. [https://web.archive.org/web/20160126222910/https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-159801792.html"Alan Geisler, 78; food chemist, hot dog hero"], ''[[The Record (Bergen County)]]'', January 9, 2009, backed up by the [[Internet Archive]] as of December 26, 2016. Accessed October 9, 2018. "Alan Geisler of Mahwah, a food chemist who created the tangy red onion sauce that pushcart vendors slather over Sabrett hot dogs, died Tuesday at his winter home in Hernando, Fla. He was 78.... In 1960, Mr. Geisler -- a Tenafly High School graduate who received a bachelor's degree in food technology from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology -- founded a company that manufactures emulsifiers, shortenings and other ingredients for the baking industry.... Mr. Geisler, a 45-year resident of Mahwah, was still active in the company he founded a half-century ago, Technical Oil Products Inc. in Boonton, said Glenn Geisler, a partner."</ref> Specifically, the sauce, which is marketed as Sabrett's Prepared Onions, is usually served on [[Sabrett]] brand hot dogs sold by New York's many [[Street food|pushcart hot dog vendors]].<ref name=RecordObit/>
Sabrett [[brand]] hot dogs and the red onion sauce which Geisler created are the [[flagship]] products of [[Marathon Enterprises, Inc.]] The company is headquartered in [[Englewood, New Jersey]].
== Personal life == Geisler was a graduate of [[Tenafly High School]] in [[Tenafly, New Jersey]].<ref name=RecordObit/> He received his bachelor's degree in [[food technology]] from the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]].<ref name=RecordObit/> He served as an officer in the Quartermaster Corps of the US Army during the Korean War.
Geisler resided in [[Mahwah, New Jersey]], for 45 years.<ref name=RecordObit/> He was an ardent stamp collector and dealer, and an original member of the Apple Ridge Golf and Country Club of Mahwah, NJ. An avid golfer with a 4 handicap at one time, he won the Club Championship in all four flights, and throughout his career eagled all 18 holes. He played the bagpipes with the Fairleigh Dickinson University Pipe Band and the Kearny Caledonian Pipe Band for several years, even performing in the St. Patrick Day Parade in NYC.
== Career == Geisler founded a company that manufactured [[shortening]]s, [[emulsifier]]s and other ingredients for the [[baking]] and [[baked goods]] industry in 1960.<ref name=RecordObit/>
One of his customers was Gregory Papalexis, who manufactured both hot dogs and [[hot dog bun]]s.<ref name=RecordObit/> Papalexis's customers included hot dog [[street vendor]]s, who often made a popular homemade, but time laborious, onion sauce as a topping.<ref name=RecordObit/> Papalexis asked Geisler to come up with a factory-made onion sauce for the hot dog vendors to sell at their carts in New York City.<ref name=RecordObit/>
Geisler, with input from Papalexis, created a new, mass-produced onion sauce for hot dogs. The main formula and [[spice blend]]s of the sauce consisted predominantly of [[onion]]s, [[olive oil]] and [[tomato paste]],<ref name=RecordObit/> which gives the sauce its distinctive red coloring.<ref name=RecordObit/> The sauce proved to be a hit with both the street vendors, who no longer had to make their own time consuming sauces, and hot dog consumers.<ref name=RecordObit/>
Geisler and Papalexis partnered to form their own company, called Tremont Foods, to market and make the new red onion sauce.<ref name=RecordObit/> The sauce was initially sold to New York City hot dogs vendors under the brand names Tremont Foods or House of Weenies.<ref name=RecordObit/>
Papalexis acquired Sabrett Food Products in 1989.<ref name=RecordObit/> As a result of the [[Takeover|acquisition]], Geisler's onion sauce became the only onion sauce served on Sabrett hot dogs by vendors in New York City.<ref name=RecordObit/> The red onion condiment also became available for purchase in [[supermarket]]s under the Sabrett's brand.<ref name=RecordObit/> It is marketed nationwide as "Sabrett's Prepared Onions."<ref name=philly>{{cite news|first= |last= |title=Alan S. Geisler, Hot dog sauce maker, 78 |url=http://www.philly.com/philly/obituaries/20090112_Alan_S__Geisler___Hot_dog_sauce_maker__78.html |work=[[Associated Press]] |publisher=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]] |date=2008-01-12 |accessdate=2009-02-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090115093046/http://www.philly.com/philly/obituaries/20090112_Alan_S__Geisler___Hot_dog_sauce_maker__78.html |archivedate=January 15, 2009 }}</ref>
As of 2009, Geisler's red onion sauce enjoys "a couple of million dollars a year in sales," according to Papalexis.<ref name=RecordObit/> Geisler's and Papalexis's original company, Tremont Foods, is currently a [[Division (business)|division]] of [[Marathon Enterprises, Inc.]], which owns the Sabrett trademark.<ref name=RecordObit/> (Marathon Enterprises is owned by Papalexis.<ref name=RecordObit/>) The only product made by Tremont Foods is the popular red onion sauce.<ref name=RecordObit/> The sauce is manufactured in [[The Bronx]], but production is scheduled to shift to a new facility, in [[Fair Lawn, New Jersey]], in 2009.<ref name=RecordObit/>
Geisler remained active with the company until his death in 2009.
== Death == Geisler died at his winter home in [[Hernando, Florida]], on January 6, 2009, at the age of 78.<ref name=RecordObit/> Geisler had been suffering from a [[protein]] [[Disease|disorder]] called [[amyloidosis]].<ref name=RecordObit/> He was survived by his wife, Jean Geisler, his daughter, Martha Geisler, his son, Glenn Geisler, his brother and a grandson.<ref name=RecordObit/>
== See also == *[[Street food]]
== References == {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Geisler, Alan}} [[Category:1930s births]] [[Category:2009 deaths]] [[Category:People from Mahwah, New Jersey]] [[Category:People from Tenafly, New Jersey]] [[Category:Massachusetts Institute of Technology alumni]] [[Category:American food scientists]] [[Category:People in food and agriculture occupations]] [[Category:People from Citrus County, Florida]] [[Category:Tenafly High School alumni]]

revision.text:
The '''Aliab Dinka''' are a subdivision of the [[Dinka people]] of [[South Sudan]]. They traditionally lived in an area west of the upper [[White Nile]] river. The name is also used to refer to a breed of cattle maintained by the Aliab Dinka people and widespread in the region.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://dagris.ilri.cgiar.org/display.asp?ID=144 |title = General Breed Information: Aliab Dinka |work = Dagris |publisher = ILRI |accessdate = 2011-08-02 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20111003053628/http://dagris.ilri.cgiar.org/display.asp?ID=144 |archive-date = 2011-10-03 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref>
==Location==
The Aliab Dinka mainly live in the [[Lakes (state)|Lakes State]] of South Sudan, in the [[Awerial County]], to the west of the White Nile.<ref name=UNMIS/> The Aliab Valley is a low floodplain to the west of the Bahr-el-Gebel (Nile) between [[Tombé]] in the south and [[Lake Papiu]] in the north. The valley is between {{convert|2.5|mi|km}} and {{convert|6|mi|km}} wide and perhaps {{convert|60|km|mi}} in length. The Bahr-el-Gebel flows well above the east side of the valley between high banks. During the rainy season, usually starting in June, the river overflows its banks and floods the whole valley, which becomes a huge swamp. After the southern half of the valley has drained, between December and April it is suitable for cattle grazing. A report from 1951 said that some Dinka hunted the abundant game during this period, particularly buffalo.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sudanarchive.net/cgi-bin/pagessoa?a=pdf&d=Dunepd100&dl=1 |title=The Game of The Aliab valley |author=J.V.Sutcliffe |work=Sudan Archive |accessdate=2011-08-02}}</ref>
==1919 rising==
In 1919 the Aliab Dinka country lay within the [[Mongalla Province]] of the [[Anglo-Egyptian Sudan]]. There was an uprising of the Aliab Dinka that year. 3,000 Dinka men attacked the police post at Mingkaman ( Guol-yier ), near [[Bor, South Sudan|Bor]], and killed several policemen. [[Mandari people|Mandari]] tribesmen in the region to the south attacked at the same time and killed some telegraph linesmen and police. Lieutenant Colonel Richard Finch White took several companies of the Egyptian Army Equatorial Battalion to the area to handle the situation.<ref name=Fecitt/> The Mongalla province Governor [[Chauncey Hugh Stigand]] went on patrol himself, and on 8 December 1919 was killed at Pap, between the Lau River and the White Nile.<ref name=Hill1967>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QS_GYMeSzRMC&pg=PA346 |chapter=Stigand Bey, Chauncey Hugh |title=A biographical dictionary of the Sudan |author=Richard Leslie Hill |publisher=Routledge |year=1967 |ISBN=0-7146-1037-2}}</ref> Two other officers and 24 soldiers and porters were speared to death by 1,000 Dinka warriors.<ref name=Fecitt/> The rising was put down harshly in 1920.<ref name=Roberts1984>{{cite book |ref=harv |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zywkdNMeltkC&pg=PA764 |page=764 |title=The Cambridge history of Africa, Volume 8 |last1=Roberts |first1=Andrew D.|first2=John Donnelly |last2=Fage |first3=Roland Anthony |last3=Oliver |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=1984 |ISBN=0-521-22505-1}}</ref> A force under Colonel Robert Henry Darwall led the punitive expedition, which killed over 400 Dinka, [[Atwot people|Atwot]] and Mandari tribesmen, burnt many villages and took about 7,000 cattle.<ref name=Fecitt/>
Stigand's successor [[Vincent Reynolds Woodland]] wrote that "The Government has done nothing for the Aliab. It has not protected them from aggression, has given them no economic benefits ... it has forced them to do a certain amount of labour, to pay taxes and to endure a not negligible amount of extortion by police". However, although he removed the Egyptian ''ma'mur'' at Minkammon who had triggered the Aliab revolt through his abuses, Woodland did not appoint a replacement. The Aliab Dinka were left with no administration at all.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=udSrM54HNK4C&pg=PA143 |pages=143–144 |title=Empire on the Nile: The Anglo-Egyptian Sudan, 1898-1934 |author=M. W. Daly |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=2004 |ISBN=0-521-89437-9}}</ref>
==Conflicts==
The Aliab Dinka have traditionally been primarily pastoral in occupation, although they engage in some agriculture.<ref name=UNMIS/> In the past, the Aliab Dinka had a close relationship with the [[Mandari people]]. In the dry season, the Mandari would graze the Aliab grasslands beside the Nile. In return, the Aliab Dinka would share the Mandari woodland grazing in the rainy season.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8b4yNLt60gYC&pg=PA69 |title=Tribes without rulers: studies in African segmentary systems |author=John Middleton, David Tait |publisher=Routledge |year=2004 |ISBN=0-415-32997-3}}</ref> In times of shortage, however, there has been conflict between the Aliab and Bor Dinka and the Mandari. During the period starting in 1972 with the end of the [[First Sudanese Civil War]] the Aliab Dinka used their control of administrative posts to undermine the old agreements on dry season grazing. When hostilities resumed in 1983 with the [[Second Sudanese Civil War]] there was a violent reaction against the Dinka, with many being killed by the Mundari in [[Juba]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.sudanvisiondaily.com/modules.php?name=News&file=print&sid=4028 |title = Eight Grassroots Conflicts in Sudan (3) |author = Paul Wani Goue |work = Sudan Vision |accessdate = 2011-08-02 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110928195705/http://www.sudanvisiondaily.com/modules.php?name=News&file=print&sid=4028 |archive-date = 2011-09-28 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref>
Conflict flared up between the Aliab Dinka and the Mandari again in November 2009. About 40 people were killed in a dispute over grazing land on the border of [[Awerial County|Aliap]] and [[Terekeka County|Terekeka]] counties during a period of water shortage. Nine of the Dinka were killed and about 31 Mundari men were shot dead by the more heavily armed Dinka. The Aliap Dinka claimed that the Mandari had been the aggressors, abducting five women and four children and stealing 20 cows.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sudanwatch.blogspot.com/2009/11/south-sudan-terkeka-county-official.html |title=Terkeka county official says about 40 people were killed last Sunday in clashes over grazing land along border of Aliap and Terkeka |work=Sudan Radio Service |date=November 19, 2009 |accessdate=2011-08-03| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110629082129/http://sudanwatch.blogspot.com/2009/11/south-sudan-terkeka-county-official.html| archivedate= 29 June 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist |refs= <ref name=Fecitt>{{cite web |url=http://peterbaxterafrica.com/index.php/2011/02/25/fighting-the-aliab-dinka-southern-sudan/ |title=Fighting the Aliab Dinka Southern Sudan, November 1919 – May 1920 |author=HARRY FECITT |date=25 February 2011 |accessdate=2011-08-02}}</ref> <ref name=UNMIS>{{cite web |url = http://unmis.unmissions.org/Portals/UNMIS/Referendum/Lakes.pdf |title = Lakes State Briefing Pack |author = Lakes State Integrated Office |date = 17 June 2010 |accessdate = 2011-08-02 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120316140940/http://unmis.unmissions.org/Portals/UNMIS/Referendum/Lakes.pdf |archive-date = 2012-03-16 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref> }} [[Category:Dinka people]]

revision.text:
{{Spanish name|Imbert|Barrera}} {{Infobox Officeholder | image =File:MG Antonio Imbert Barrera.jpg | imagesize = | smallimage = | caption = | order = 44th | office = President of the Dominican Republic | term_start = May 7, 1965 | term_end = August 30, 1965 | vicepresident = None | predecessor = [[Pedro Bartolomé Benoit]] | successor = [[Héctor García-Godoy]] | office2 = [[List of Dominican Secretary of Armed Forces|Minister of Defense of the Dominican Republic]] | term_start2 = October 8, 1986 | term_end2 = June 17, 1988 | president2 = [[Joaquín Balaguer]] | predecessor2 = [[Víctor M. Barjan Muffdi]] | successor2 = [[Elías Wessin y Wessin]] | birth_date = {{birth date|1920|12|3}} | birth_place = [[San Felipe de Puerto Plata]], Dominican Republic | death_date = {{death date and age|2016|5|31|1920|12|3}} | death_place =[[Santo Domingo]], Dominican Republic | nationality = Dominican | party = | otherparty = | father = Segundo Manuel Imbert Mesnier | mother = María del Consuelo Barrera Steinkopf | spouse = {{plainlist| *Giralda Busto Sánchez *Guarina Mercedes Tessón Hurtado *María Sánchez }} | partner = | relations = [[Carmen Imbert Brugal]] (niece)
[[Segundo Imbert]] (grandfather)
[[José María Imbert]] (great-grandfather) | children = 4 | residence = | alma_mater = | occupation = | profession = [[Army]] [[Major General]] | signature = | website = | footnotes = }} Major General '''Antonio Cosme Imbert Barrera''' (December 3, 1920[https://books.google.com/books?id=HEFACwAAQBAJ&pg=PA175&dq=Antonio+Imbert+Barrera+1920&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwihn7_UxJPUAhUL3SwKHS5WDmsQ6AEIKDAC#v=onepage&q=Antonio%20Imbert%20Barrera%201920&f=false] – May 31, 2016) was a [[Two-star rank|two-star]] [[Major general|army general]] advitam of the [[Dominican Army]] and was [[List of Presidents of the Dominican Republic|President of the Dominican Republic]] from May to August 1965. Imbert, who plotted to assassinate dictator [[Rafael Trujillo]] in 1961, was one of the two rival rulers in the [[Dominican Republic]] from May 7, 1965 until August 30, 1965, amid the [[Dominican Civil War]]. He had succeeded General [[Pedro Bartolomé Benoit|Pedro B. Benoit van der Horst]] who ruled for less than a week. After the civil war ended, both General Imbert and his rival Colonel [[Francisco Caamaño]] resigned and [[Héctor García-Godoy]], a civilian, was sworn as interim president. ==Early life== Imbert was born into a prominent family of military tradition: his father, Brigadier General Segundo Manuel Imbert Mesnier had a leading role in the [[Cibao|northern region]] of the [[Dominican Republic]]; Brigadier General [[Segundo Imbert|Segundo Francisco Imbert]], Imbert Barrera’s grandfather, was Vice-President of the Dominican Republic and candidate for President, and fought in the [[Dominican Restoration War]]; meanwhile his great-grandfather, Major General [[José María Imbert]], who was a French migrant, achieved important victories against Haiti in the [[Dominican War of Independence]]. Imbert’s first significant position was as governor of [[Puerto Plata province|Puerto Plata]] in 1940. He was removed from the post by then president [[Rafael Trujillo]] for sending him a telegram informing upon the names of the survivors of the failed {{Interlanguage link multi|Luperón invasion|de|3=Invasion bei Luperón}}. This caused, in a personal manner, the beginning of the assassination plan against Trujillo. His brother Segundo, an army official too, was imprisoned in 1956 by Trujillo’s regime. Segundo was convicted for murder;{{cite book|last1=Ornes|first1=Germán E.|title=Trujillo: pequeño César del Caribe|year=1960|publisher=Editorial Las Novedades|location=Caracas|page=189|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=M6TUAAAAMAAJ&hl=es&sa=X&redir_esc=y|accessdate=2 June 2016}}https://books.google.com/books?id=tXgaAQAAIAAJ&q=Segundo+Manuel+Imbert&dq=Segundo+Manuel+Imbert&hl=es&sa=X&redir_esc=y implicated in the murder of Domingo Marión in 1943.{{cite news|last1=Reyes |first1=Francisco |title=Acusan hermanos Imbert Barreras crímen en Puerto Plata en 1943 |url=http://www.almomento.net/acusan-hermanos-imbert-barreras-crimen-en-puerto-plata-en-1943/216766 |accessdate=16 June 2016 |publisher=Al Momento |date=16 June 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160616224721/http://www.almomento.net/acusan-hermanos-imbert-barreras-crimen-en-puerto-plata-en-1943/216766 |archivedate=16 June 2016 |location=Santo Domingo |language=Spanish |deadurl=no |df= }} ==Assassination of Trujillo== On May 30, 1961 Trujillo was shot dead when his car was ambushed on a road outside the Dominican capital.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-13560512 |title='I shot the cruellest dictator in the Americas' |date=27 May 2011 |publisher=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=13 November 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/638nXkECg?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-13560512 |archivedate=12 November 2011 |deadurl=no |df= }} Imbert, the driver of the ambushing vehicle, was accompanied by [[Antonio de la Maza]], [[Salvador Estrella Sahdalá]] and [[Amado García Guerrero]] - the active participants who carried out the plot. Most of those involved in the assassination plot were subsequently captured and executed, with the exception of Imbert and [[Luis Amiama Tió]]. Imbert went into hiding until December 2.{{cite book |last=Diederich |first=Bernard |authorlink=Bernard Diederich |title=Trujillo. The Death of the Goat |publisher=Little, Brown, and Co., 1978 |page=253 |isbn=0-316-18440-3}}{{rp|253}} After [[Joaquín Balaguer]], Trujillo’s figurehead president, was overthrown in 1962 and the Trujillo family was ousted, Imbert was declared a "National Hero" and was promoted to [[Major general|Major General]] with the special grant of it being ''advitam'' or lifelong. In the [[Dominican Civil War|Civil War in the Dominican Republic]] of 1965 he led one of the factions in the struggle which faced the constitutionalist government led by Colonel [[Francisco Caamaño]], who tried to bring back [[Juan Bosch (politician)|Juan Bosch]] to the country's presidency. Imbert's faction, called the [[Government of National Reconstruction]] was endorsed by the U.S. troops inspectors, in addition, he was one of the collaborators with the Americans, finally signing a peace act that put an end to the April war.{{citation needed|date=June 2016}} ==Later life== On March 21, 1967, he was shot in Santo Domingo while traveling with Marino García,{{rp|256}} in an attempted assassination made by the late dictator Trujillo's supporters. He survived by driving himself to a medical clinic. On February 15, 1970 the [[Dominicana de Aviación]] flight wherein his sister Aída Imbert Barrera, his wife Guarina Tessón Hurtado, and his daughter, sportswoman Leslie Imbert Tessón, were travelling, [[Dominicana DC-9 air disaster|crashed into the Caribbean Sea]].{{cite news|last1=Herrera|first1=Dalton|authorlink1=Dalton Herrera|title=Adiós al último héroe que ajustició a Trujillo|url=http://edition.pagesuite-professional.co.uk//launch.aspx?pbid=d1a2c233-1537-4b0a-993e-57babf45a7b1|accessdate=3 June 2016|newspaper=[[Listín Diario]]|publication-date=1 June 2016|publication-place=Santo Domingo|page=6A|format=aspx|language=Spanish}}{{cite news|title=Editorial: Adiós a un Héroe Nacional|url=http://www.listindiario.com/editorial/2016/06/01/421433/adios-a-un-heroe-nacional|accessdate=3 June 2016|newspaper=[[Listín Diario]]|publication-date=1 June 2016|language=Spanish}} He was [[Ministry of Defence|Minister of Defense]] of the Dominican Republic from 1986 to 1988; earlier that decade, his second-cousin [[Mario Imbert McGregor]] was also Minister of Defense. In 1989 he was assigned [[chairman]] of the [[board of directors]] of [[Rosario Dominicana]]. In September 2013, the ''Constitutionalist Soldiers of 25 April 1965 Foundation'' asked the [[National Congress of the Dominican Republic]] to explore the possibility of stripping Imbert his status of national hero as it considered that he went against constitutional precepts when he supported the coup against Bosch and the [[United States occupation of the Dominican Republic (1965–66)|U.S. occupation of the country]], mong other accusations.{{cite news|last1=Apolinar|first1=Bethania|title=Constitucionalistas piden despojar a Imbert Barrera de condición de Héroe Nacional|url=http://www.listindiario.com.do/la-republica/2013/9/3/290753/Constitucionalistas-Piden-despojar-a-Imbert-Barreras-de-condicion-de-Heroe|accessdate=3 June 2016|newspaper=[[Listín Diario]]|date=3 September 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130904231439/http://www.listindiario.com/la-republica/2013/9/3/290753/Constitucionalistas-Piden-despojar-a-Imbert-Barreras-de-condicion-de-Heroe|archivedate=4 September 2013|location=Santo Domingo|language=Spanish}} Imbert died on May 31, 2016, the day following the fifty-fifth anniversary of Trujillo's assassination, at the age of 95. Dominican President [[Danilo Medina]] declared three days of [[mourning]].{{cite news|last1=Abiú López|first1=Ezequiel|title=Ex-Dominican president who helped topple dictator dies at 95|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/the_americas/ex-dominican-president-who-helped-topple-dictator-dies-at-95/2016/05/31/bd637598-275d-11e6-8329-6104954928d2_story.html|accessdate=4 June 2016|agency=Associated Press|publisher=[[The Washington Post]]|date=31 May 2016|location=Santo Domingo}}{{cite news|title=Antonio Imbert Barrera, who toppled Dominican dictator, dies|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-36423145|accessdate=4 June 2016|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=1 June 2016}} His niece, [[Carmen Imbert Brugal]], said that [[Cause of death|cause of his death]] was complications of [[pneumonia]].{{cite news|last1=Semple|first1=Kirk|title=Antonio Imbert Barrera, Who Helped Assassinate Dominican Dictator Trujillo, Dies at 95|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/08/world/americas/antonio-imbert-barrera-who-helped-assassinate-dominican-dictator-trujillo-dies-at-95.html?_r=0|accessdate=11 June 2016|publisher=[[The New York Times]]|date=7 June 2016|location=Mexico City}} === Marriages and family === He married Guarina Tessón Hurtado on September 10, 1939 in Puerto Plata. They had three children:{{cite|last1=Arthur|first1=Víctor|authorlink1=Víctor Arthur Nouel|title=Descendencia de José María Imbert}} *Antonio Segundo Imbert Tessón (born June 9, 1940), army general. He married Victoria Isabel Pellerano Amiama (niece of Luis Amiama Tió) and had 3 children. *Leslie Imbert Tessón (1949–[[Dominicana Flight 603|February 15, 1970]]), sportswoman. Died childless in an aircraft accident. *Oscar José Antonio Imbert Tessón (born December 30, 1953), architect. He designed the [[Punta Cana International Airport]]. He married Margarita Pou Guerra and had 1 children and divorced. He remarried to Solange Juliette Martín-Caro Lithgow, but later divorced with no children being begotten from this marriage. He had a liaison with María Sánchez, from [[Sosúa]], and begat Manuel Antonio Imbert Sánchez (born April 1, 1939), police officer and former diplomat; Imbert Sánchez is a [[colonel]] and is married (to Josefina López Henríquez) with 4 children and he is since 2012 the chief of the Special Police Corps for State Banks, he also was consul to the United States in [[Charlotte Amalie, United States Virgin Islands|Charlotte Amalie]], [[United States Virgin Islands|U.S. Virgin Islands]] in the 1980s and the 1990s.{{cite book|title=Foreign Consular Offices in the U.S.|date=September 1991|publisher=United States Department of State|location=Washington, D. C.|page=18}}http://acento.com.do/2017/opinion/8472241-quincuagesimo-quinto-presidente-rd-general-antonio-imbert-barrera/http://hoy.com.do/capsulas-genealogicas-30-de-mayo-sus-heroes/ His wife died in 1970 in an aircraft accident. After widowing Imbert Barrera remarried to Giralda Busto Sánchez, but had no children from this marriage.http://www.listindiario.com/la-republica/2016/06/02/421564/la-viuda-de-imbert-revela-mensaje-secreto-del-heroe ==Ancestry== {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes |align=center |boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; |boxstyle_4=background-color: #bfc; |boxstyle_5=background-color: #9fe; | 1= 1. '''Antonio Cosme Imbert Barrera''' (1920–2016)
[[Puerto Plata (city)|Puerto Plata]], [[Dominican Republic]] | 2= 2. Segundo Manuel Imbert Mesnier (1876–1921)
[[Puerto Plata (city)|Puerto Plata]], [[Dominican Republic]] | 3= 3. María del Consuelo Barrera Steinkopf (1894–1980)

revision.text:
{{for|the FBI agent|Bassem Youssef (FBI agent)}} {{Infobox comedian | name = Bassem Youssef | alt = Bassem Youssef | image = Bassem Youssef.jpg | caption = Bassem at [[Chatham House]] London Conference 2016 | birth_name = Bassem Raafat Muhammad Youssef | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1974|3|22|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Cairo]], [[Egypt]] | death_date = | death_place = | alma_mater = [[Cairo University]] | medium = [[Stand-up comedy|Stand-up]], [[television]], [[books]] | genre = [[Political satire|Political]]/[[news satire]], [[observational comedy]], [[surreal comedy]], [[black comedy]], [[sarcasm]], [[insult comedy]] | subject =[[Mass media]]/[[news media]]/[[media studies|media criticism]], [[politics of the United States|American politics]], [[Egyptian culture]], [[current events]], [[religion]], [[popular culture|pop culture]], [[race relations]], [[racism]], [[human sexuality]] | active = 2011–present | spouse = {{marriage|Hala Diab|2010}} | children = 2 | notable_works = {{unbulleted list |''[[Al Bernameg]]'' |''The B+ Show''}} }}
'''Bassem Raafat Muhammad Youssef''' ({{lang-arz|باسم رأفت محمد يوسف}}, {{IPA-arz|ˈbæːsem ˈɾɑʔfɑt mæˈħæmmæd ˈjuːsef|IPA}}; born 22 March 1974) is an [[Egyptian people|Egyptian]] comedian, writer, producer, surgeon, [[physician]], media critic, and television host, who hosted ''[[Al Bernameg|El-Bernameg]]'' (''The Show''), a satirical news program, from 2011 to 2014. The press has compared Youssef with American comedian [[Jon Stewart]], whose satire program ''[[The Daily Show]]'' inspired Youssef to begin his career.<ref>{{cite news|last=El-Wakil|first=Mai|title=Drawing inspiration from the revolution |url=http://www.egyptindependent.com/news/egyptians-find-their-voice-after-years-repression|newspaper=Al Masry Al Youm|date=21 April 2011|access-date=9 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Marx|first=Willem|title=Bassem Youssef: Egypt's Jon Stewart|url=http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2012-03-29/bassem-youssef-egypts-jon-stewart#p1|newspaper=Bloomberg Businessweek|date=29 March 2012|access-date=9 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Hassan|first=Abdalla|title=Surgeon Using Parody to Dissect the News in Egypt|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/28/world/middleeast/28iht-M28C-EGYPT-SHOW.html|newspaper=New York Times|date=28 April 2011|access-date=9 January 2014}}</ref> In 2013, he was named one of the "[[Time 100|100 most influential people in the world]]" by ''Time'' magazine.<ref>{{cite news|title=Bassem Youssef|url=http://time100.time.com/2013/04/18/time-100/slide/bassem-youssef/|newspaper=Time|date=18 April 2013|access-date=9 January 2014}}</ref> Youssef's current projects are ''[[Tickling Giants]]'', ''The Democracy Handbook'', and ''Revolution For Dummies''.<ref>{{cite news|last=|first=|title= Life after Egypt for Bassem Youssef: Deflect hecklers; For Egyptian political satirist Bassem Youssef, deflecting hecklers is part of his routine. |url= http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/04/life-egypt-bassem-youssef-deflect-hecklers-160428100041278.html|newspaper= Al Jazeera |date= 4 May 2016 |access-date= 9 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=|first=|title= 'An Evening with Bassem Youssef'|url= https://www.nytimes.com/events/comedy/an-evening-with-bassem-youssef-31239.html|newspaper= NYT |date= 24 April 2011|access-date= 9 May 2016}}</ref>
==Medical career== Bassem Youssef graduated from [[Cairo University]]'s Faculty of Medicine, majoring in [[cardiothoracic surgery]], in 1998. He passed the [[United States Medical Licensing Examination]] and has been a member of the Royal College of Surgeons ([[Membership of the Royal College of Surgeons|MRCS]]) since February 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rcseng.ac.uk/patients/the-surgical-team/finding-a-surgeon?searchableText=Bassem%20Youssef&membership_type=&name_type=|title=Surgical Staff & Regulation — Royal College of Surgeons|first=|last=sitecore\lewis.ashman@rcseng.ac.uk|publisher=}}</ref> He also received training in cardiac and lung transplantation in Germany, after which he spent a year and a half in the US working for a company that produces medical equipment related to cardiothoracic surgery. In January 2011, Youssef assisted the wounded in [[Tahrir Square]] during the Egyptian revolution.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/5/35/19963/Arts--Culture/Stage--Street/Revolutionary-satire-Bassem-Youssef-speaks-to-Ahra.aspx|title=Revolutionary satire: Bassem Youssef speaks to Ahram Online|work=ahram.org.eg}}</ref>
==Media career==
===''The B+ Show'' (March 2011)=== Inspired by the [[Egyptian revolution of 2011]], Youssef created his first satirical show in March 2011. Entitled ''The B+ Show'' after his blood type,<ref>{{cite web |last=Gladstone |first=Brooke |title=Egypt Finds Its Own 'Jon Stewart' |work=NPR|date=15 April 2011|access-date=9 January 2014|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/transcript/transcript.php?storyId=135444956}}</ref> the program, at 5 minutes per episode, was uploaded to his [[YouTube]] channel in May 2011<ref>{{cite news|last=Elkayal|first=Heba|title=Comedy show du jour: Bassem Youssef's Al-Bernameg|url=http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2011/09/07/comedy-show-du-jour-bassem-youssefs-al-bernameg/|newspaper=Daily News Egypt|date=7 September 2011|access-date=9 January 2014}}</ref> and gained more than five million views in the first three months alone.<ref name="cairo360.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.cairo360.com/article/tvanddvd/1619/cairo-360-presents-the-bassem-youssef-show-b|title=Cairo 360 Presents: The Bassem Youssef Show (B+) - TV & DVD Feature - Cairo 360|work=cairo360.com}}</ref> The show was shot in Youssef's laundry room using a table, a chair, one camera, and a mural of amateur photos from Tahrir Square that cost $100. The show was a collaboration by Youssef with [[Tarek ElKazzaz]], Amr Ismail, Mohamed Khalifa, and Mostafa Al-Halawany. Youssef used social media to showcase his talent and his show gave a voice to the millions of Egyptians who were seething with anger from the traditional media's coverage of the Egyptian Revolution.
===''Al Bernameg'' Season 1 (September 2011)=== After the success of ''The B+ Show'', Egyptian channel [[ONTV (Egypt)|ONTV]], owned by Egyptian billionaire [[Naguib Sawiris]], offered Youssef a deal for ''Al Bernameg'' (literally, "The Program"). With a budget of roughly half a million dollars, the series made him the first Internet to TV conversion in the Middle East.<ref>{{cite news|last=Montasser|first=Farah|title=Revolutionary Satire|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/09/02/165062.html|access-date=2 September 2011|newspaper=Al Arabiya|author2=Deena Adel}}</ref> The show, which consisted of 104 episodes, premiered during [[Ramadan]] 1432 (2011) with Egyptian-American engineer Muhammad Radwan as its first guest.<ref>{{cite news|title=Interview with Mohamed Radwan|url=http://www.syrianrevolution2011.com/videos/player/tabid/68/videoid/2857/---------interview-with-mohamed-radwan-the-program-with-basem-yousef-20110731.aspx|date=31 July 2011|access-date=9 January 2014}}</ref> In his show, Youssef has parodied such Egyptian celebrities as show host [[Tawfik Okasha]], composer [[Amr Mostafa]], [[Salafi movement|Salafist]] presidential candidate [[Hazem Salah Abu Ismail]], and [[Mohamed ElBaradei]], former head of the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]] and onetime presidential candidate. The show became the platform for many writers, artists, and politicians to speak freely about the social and political scene. ''Al-Bernameg'''s success inspired a number of amateur initiatives on various social media channels, who credit ''The B+ Show'' as their inspiration.<ref name="cairo360.com"/>
===''The Daily Show'' 2012=== In June 2012, Jon Stewart invited Youssef to ''The Daily Show'' for an extended interview, "...I do know a little something about the humour business; your show is sharp, you're really good on it, it's smart, it's well executed, I think the world of what you're doing down there," Stewart said to Youssef. The segment was one of the highest in viewership on the ''Daily Show''{{'}}s website.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thedailyshow.cc.com/videos/okmooj/exclusive---bassem-youssef-extended-interview-pt--2|title=Exclusive - Bassem Youssef Extended Interview Pt. 2|work=cc.com}}</ref>
===''Al Bernameg'' Season 2 (November 2012)=== Following the success of ''The B+ Show'' on YouTube and the first season of ''Al-Bernameg'' on ONTV, [[Tarek ElKazzaz]] convinced an old friend, [[Ahmed Abbas]], to join QSoft as chief operations officer and Project Director for ''Al-Bernameg'' with the mission of developing and upgrading the show into a multifaceted and global brand. This was done with the help of a team that covered many disciplines, including marketing, operations, legal and public relations. This all helped in developing both Bassem Youssef and ''Al-Bernameg'' on all levels and created a global audience. The show ''Al Bernameg'' was renewed for a second season after a contract with a second channel, CBC ([[Capital Broadcast Center]]), which premiered on November 23, 2012. The second season consisted of 29 episodes and has recorded one of the highest viewership ratings on both TV and internet with 40 million viewers on TV and more than 184 million combined views for his show on YouTube alone. Just three episodes into the show, several lawsuits were filed against Bassem Youssef and his show, mainly for "insult and defamation". On the season's premiere, Youssef made the owner and coworkers of his channel the subject of his show, as an assurance that he is granted full freedom of expression, and that no topic was off limits.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2012/12/08/254037.html|title=Egyptian comedy show takes on 'merchants of religion'|publisher=AlArabiya|date=8 December 2012|access-date=27 December 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3Un7YwQtQ1M|title=Egypt satire show sparks media clash |publisher=Al Arabiya|date=November 2012|access-date=9 January 2014}}</ref> CBC did not, however, air his second episode, which also featured further criticism of a TV show host who filed a lawsuit against Youssef. The show returned to its regular schedule for the third episode.
The program, which began with a small group working at home with Youssef, moved from ONTV's smallest studio to Radio theater in downtown Cairo, a theatre redesigned in the likeness of [[NBC Radio City Studios|New York's Radio City]], making it the first live audience show in the Middle East.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}} The contents of a typical show's broadcast have evolved, which began with a sarcastic take on current political events, and eventually incorporating the hosting of public figures and stars from various fields, as well as various artists' performances. In November 2012, ''Al-Bernameg''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.albernameg.com/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-02-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140106125405/http://www.albernameg.com/ |archivedate=2014-01-06 |df= }}</ref> moved from ONTV's<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ontveg.com/|title=ONtv Official Website – الموقع الرسمي لقناة أون تي في - الموقع الرسمي لقناة أون تي في – ONtv Official Website|work=ONtv Official Website - الموقع الرسمي لقناة أون تي في}}</ref> smallest studio to Radio Theatre<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/pages/Radio-TheaterDown-Town-Cairo/173511029436584|title=Radio Theater"Down Town Cairo"|work=facebook.com}}</ref> in Cairo's downtown. Following the move, Youssef succeeded in increasing the show's worth by eight times in one year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.egyptindependent.com//news/profile-bassem-youssef-professionalizes-satire|title=Profile: Bassem Youssef professionalizes satire - Egypt Independent|work=egyptindependent.com}}</ref><ref>[[ONTV (Egypt)]]</ref> The second season, which premiered in November 2012 on CBC network, was the first real live audience show in Egypt. The show gained tremendous success through its criticism of former Egyptian President [[Mohammed Morsi|Mohamed Morsi]], representing the [[Muslim Brotherhood]]. Soon after the show started airing, complaints were filed against Youssef, accusing him of insulting [[Islam]], Morsi and disrupting public order and peace.
===''Al-Shorouk''=== In March 2013, Bassem Youssef started writing a weekly column expressing his views for ''[[Al-Shorouk]]''; one of Egypt's most prominent and independent daily newspapers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shorouknews.com/columns/Basem-youssef|title=رأي - باسم يوسف - بوابة الشروق|work=shorouknews.com}}</ref>
Youssef also wrote newspaper columns, where he tackled taboo subjects such as atheism and questioning the commonly held view that [[Apostasy in Islam|apostasy from Islam]] should be punishable by death.<ref>{{cite news|title=Youth: Give us a chance|url=https://www.economist.com/news/special-report/21580627-lots-young-people-and-few-decent-jobs-are-recipe-trouble-give-us-chance|publisher=Economist|date=11 July 2013|access-date=9 January 2014}}</ref> On March 18, 2014, he faced plagiarism accusations by his readers, and through Twitter, by the original British writer, [[Ben Judah]], who wrote the article for ''[[Politico]]'' magazine. He later published an apology in ''El Sherouk'' newspaper for initially publishing an article without citing any references.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bassem Youssef 'very sorry' after plagiarism accusations|url=http://thecairopost.com/news/102869/news/bassem-youssef-very-sorry-after-plagiarism-accusations|publisher=The Cairo Post|date=19 March 2014|access-date=20 March 2014}}</ref>
===''America in Arabic''=== As ''Al-Bernameg'' continued with its growing success, Jon Stewart appeared as a guest on the show in June 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.upworthy.com/jon-stewart-of-america-meets-the-jon-stewart-of-egypt-and-hilarity-ensues|title=Jon Stewart Of America Meets The Jon Stewart Of Egypt, And Hilarity Ensues|work=Upworthy}}</ref>
On 1 July 2013 ''America in Arabic''<ref>{{IMDb title | id= 3157422 | title= America in Arabic | description= Bassem Youssef comes to America and discuss the love/hate relationships Arabs have towards the United States. 30 episode show. | section= combined }}</ref> (United Arab Emirates) debuted.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://vimeo.com/70127458|title=America In Arabic Episode 01 |publisher=[[Vimeo]]|website=Vimeo.com|access-date=25 January 2018}}</ref> He appeared for the second time on ''The Daily Show ''with Jon Stewart.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thedailyshow.cc.com/videos/hiwtrs/bassem-youssef|title=Bassem Youssef|work=cc.com}}</ref>
===CBC stops airing=== After a four-month break, Youssef appeared on air in October 2013, with a show that stirred much controversy and criticism.{{citation needed|date=March 2017}} In response to the popular criticism and discontent the show caused, CBC, the show's broadcaster, distanced itself from the show and its creators, and decided to stop airing it on its channels. Meanwhile, more than 30 complaints against Youssef and the show were filed at the General Prosecutor's office, accusing him of insulting the [[Egyptian Armed Forces]] and President [[Adly Mansour]] and describing the June 30 protests as a military coup, in addition to disrupting public order and peace. The General Prosecutor transferred some of the complaints for investigation, which were subject to the prosecutor's decision and judgment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailynewsegypt.com/2012/12/02/bassem-youssefs-el-bernameg-in-trouble-on-cbc/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121206051735/http://dailynewsegypt.com/2012/12/02/bassem-youssefs-el-bernameg-in-trouble-on-cbc/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=6 December 2012|title=Bassem Youssef's El-Bernameg in trouble on CBC|date=2 December 2012|publisher=}}</ref>
===''Al Bernameg'' Season 3 (October 2013)=== After terminating the contract with CBC, the production company behind ''Al Bernameg'' received offers from different TV channels. The third season was scheduled to air during the first quarter of 2014. In February 2014 it was announced that Youssef had signed a deal with the [[Middle East Broadcasting Center]] and that they would start broadcasting ''Al Bernameg'' from 7 February on [[MBC MASR]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://news.yahoo.com/egyptian-satirist-signs-contract-network-185153886.html |title=Egyptian satirist signs contract with new network |last1=Hyde |first1=Maggie |date=1 February 2014 |website=[[Yahoo! News]] |accessdate=2 February 2014}}</ref> However the program was suspended by MBC during the [[Egyptian presidential election, 2014|2014 Egyptian presidential election campaign]], and in June 2014 Youssef announced that he was ending ''Al-Bernameg'' as he felt that the political climate in Egypt was too dangerous to continue the show.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2014/jun/02/bassem-youssef-closes-egyptian-satire-tv-show-over-safety-fears |title=Egyptian satirist Bassem Youssef winds up TV show due to safety fears |last1=Kingsley |first1=Patrick|date=2 June 2014 |website=[[theguardian.com]] |accessdate=3 June 2014}}</ref>
After a four-month break, ''Al Bernameg'' returned to air for its third series on 25 October 2013. The season premiere marked the first broadcast for the show since the [[2013 Egyptian coup d'état]] had deposed Mohamed Morsi from the Egyptian presidency. Youssef criticised both the Morsi administration and the people's idolization of the Egyptian Defense Minister [[Abdul Fatah al-Sisi]]. The following day the CBC network issued a statement distancing the channel from the political stance taken by Youssef. The CBC network issued another statement, and decided to stop broadcasting ''Al Bernameg'' because of violations in the contract signed.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2013/oct/28/egyptian-satirist-bassem-youssef-returns|title=Egyptian satirist Bassem Youssef upsets all sides on return to TV |last1=Kingsley|first1=Patrick|agency=The Guardian|date=28 October 2013|accessdate=9 January 2014}}</ref>
''Al-Bernameg'' reappeared on MBC Masr<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mbc.net/ar/mbc-maser.html|title=MBC.net - الرئيسية - MBC مصر|work=mbc.net}}</ref> satellite channel on February 7, 2014, achieving unprecedented weekly viewership ratings for 11 consecutive weeks. In June 2014, and after a six-week break, the ''Al-Bernameg'' team held a press conference where Youssef announced the termination of the show due to pressure on both the show and the airing channel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/media/television-and-radio/2014/02/08/Egypt-s-Bassem-Youssef-returns-to-the-air-on-MBC.html|title=Egypt’s Bassem Youssef returns to the air on MBC|website=English.AlArabiya.net|access-date=25 January 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2014/06/jon-stewart-farewell-to-egyptian-satire-bassem-youssef-show-cancelled-pressure-video-739390/|title=Jon Stewart Bids Farewell To Egyptian Satire As Pal Bassem Youssef's Show Cancelled (Video) - Deadline|author=Nancy Tartaglione|work=Deadline}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/jon-stewart-of-egypt-bassem-youssef/|title="The Jon Stewart of Egypt": Bassem Youssef|date=8 June 2014|work=cbsnews.com}}</ref>
===After ''Al Bernameg''=== In January 2015, [[Harvard Institute of Politics|Harvard's Institute of Politics]] (IOP), at the [[John F. Kennedy School of Government]], announced that Youssef would be a resident fellow for the spring semester.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iop.harvard.edu/blog/spring-2015-resident-and-visiting-fellows|title=Spring 2015 Resident and Visiting Fellows|work=The Institute of Politics at Harvard University}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iop.harvard.edu/current-fellows|title=Spring 2015 Fellows|work=The Institute of Politics at Harvard University}}</ref>
In February 2015, it was announced that Youssef was collaborating with ''The Daily Show'' producer Sara Taksler<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1582846/|title=Sara Taksler|work=IMDb}}</ref> to launch a crowd-funding campaign for her documentary about his experience, ''[[Tickling Giants]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/5/32/122699/Arts--Culture/Film/Tickling-Giants,-a-documentary-on-satirist-Bassem-.aspx|title=Tickling Giants, a documentary on satirist Bassem Youssef, launches crowd funding campaign|work=ahram.org.eg}}</ref> The movie launched in March 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/tickling_giants/|title=Tickling Giants|website=RottenTomatoes.com|access-date=25 January 2018}}</ref>
In November 2015, Bassem hosted the [[43rd International Emmy Awards]] in New York City.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Awards - Awards Gala - International Academy of Television Arts & Sciences|url = http://www.iemmys.tv/awards_gala.aspx|website = www.iemmys.tv|accessdate = 2015-12-10}}</ref>
In February 2016, it was announced that Youssef had reached a deal with [[Fusion (TV channel)|Fusion]] to produce a digital series, ''Democracy Handbook with Bassem Youssef''.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/2016/tv/news/bassem-youssef-the-democracy-handbook-fusion-f-comedy-1201695044/ |title=Bassem Youssef to Host Satirical Series for Fusion's New Digital Platform F-Comedy |last=Wagmeister |first=Elizabeth|author-link=Elizabeth Wagmeister|date=2 February 2016 |website=[[variety.com]] |access-date=29 July 2016}}</ref> The show premiered online and in a one-hour broadcast special in mid-July 2016.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/bassem-youssef-of-al-bernameg-on-new-web-series-fusion-the-democracy-handbook/ |title=The "Jon Stewart of Egypt" pokes fun at U.S. politics in "The Democracy Handbook" |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=7 July 2016 |website=[[CBS News]]|access-date=29 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aDGBYbiIzKg|title=Putting Out the UnWelcome Mat • Democracy Handbook with Bassem Youssef Ep. 1|first=|last=Fusion|date=14 July 2016|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aMgpzEuAMwA|title=Same Old Change • Democracy Handbook with Bassem Youssef Ep. 10|first=|last=Fusion|date=14 July 2016|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref>
''[[Tickling Giants]]'', a documentary film about Bassem Youssef directed by Sara Taksler, was released in 2016. In 2017 Youssef guest-starred in the [[DuckTales (2017 TV series)|''DuckTales'' reboot]] episode "The Living Mummies of Toth-Ra!" as the titular pharaoh.
The podcast ''Remade in America'' debuted In early 2018, in which Youssef explores the cultural, political, and social nuances of America from an outsider's perspective.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cafe.com/series/re-made-in-america/|title=Re-Made In America – CAFE|website=www.cafe.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/remade-in-america-with-bassem-youssef/id1376077598|title=Remade in America with Bassem Youssef by CAFE on Apple Podcasts|website=Apple Podcasts|language=en|access-date=2018-07-03}}</ref>
==Response of Egyptian government== On 1 January 2013, the daily ''[[Al-masry Al-youm]]'' reported that an Egyptian prosecutor was investigating Bassem Youssef on charges of maligning [[President of Egypt|President]] [[Mohammed Morsi]], whose office claimed that Youssef's show was "circulating false news likely to disturb public peace and public security and affect the administration."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/2013/01/01/host-of-egyptian-daily-show-investigated-after-being-accused-of-insulting-president-morsi/|title=Host of Egyptian 'Daily Show' investigated after being accused of insulting President Morsi|agency=Associated Press|date=1 January 2013|accessdate=9 January 2014}}</ref>
Despite all of the controversy it sparks, ''Al Bernameg'' has been a major success.<ref name=alarabiya_blurb>{{Cite news|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/authors/Bassem-Youssef.html|title=Bassem Youssef|agency=Al Arabiya|accessdate=9 January 2014}}</ref> It is constantly topping the regional YouTube charts, making Bassem Youssef's YouTube channel the most subscribed to in Egypt.<ref name=alarabiya_blurb/>
On 30 March 2013, an arrest warrant was issued for Youssef for allegedly insulting [[Islam]] and Morsi. The move was seen by opponents as part of an effort to silence dissent against Morsi's government.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/85402/Egypt/Politics-/Freedoms-in-Egypt-questioned-after-ElBernamegs-sus.aspx|title=Freedoms in Egypt questioned after El-Bernameg's suspension|agency=Ahram Online|date=2 November 2013|accessdate=9 January 2014}}</ref> Youssef confirmed the arrest warrant on his [[Twitter]] account and said he would hand himself in to the prosecutor's office, jokingly adding, "Unless they kindly send a police van today and save me the transportation hassle."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/03/30/bassem-youssef-arrest-warrant-egypt-jon-stewart_n_2985235.html|title=Arrest Warrant Issued For Bassem Youssef, TV Satirist Known As 'Egypt's Jon Stewart'|agency=Associated Press|date=30 June 2013|accessdate=9 January 2014|work=Huffington Post}}</ref> The following day, he was questioned by authorities before being released on bail of 15,000 Egyptian pounds.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2013/03/20133318332892628.html|title=Egypt satirist questioned for insulting Morsi|agency=Al Jazeera English|date=31 March 2013|accessdate=9 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/04/01/world/middleeast/bassem-youssef-posts-bail-as-egyptian-authorities-press-case.html|title=Egyptian Satirist Posts Bail as Authorities Press Case|agency=New York Times|date=31 March 2013|accessdate=9 January 2014|work=The New York Times|first1=Kareem|last1=Fahim}}</ref> The event sparked international media attention<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2013/04/02/Worldwide-support-for-Egyptian-satirist-s-fight-for-free-speech.html|title=Worldwide support for Egyptian satirist's fight for free speech|agency=Al Arabiya|date=2 April 2013|accessdate=9 January 2014}}</ref> as well as a segment on Jon Stewart's ''The Daily Show'' in which he declared his support for Youssef, calling him a "friend" and "brother".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LyDOAQNsTrI|title=The Daily Show: Egypt, Mohamed Morsi, and Bassem Youssef|agency=YouTube|date=2 April 2013|accessdate=9 January 2014}}</ref>
After ''Al Bernameg'' ended, the Egyptian police raided the offices of the production company, arresting several employees and confiscating their computers. According to Youssef, the police told producer Amr Ismail that they would continue harassing the company if Youssef did not stop speaking publicly at international conferences. The Egyptian courts then levied a E£50 million fine against Youssef in a contract dispute with CBC. In the verdict, the courts condemned satirical television shows and implied that Youssef was disrupting the peace and inciting public unrest. Fearing he would be arrested if he stayed in Egypt, Youssef fled to Dubai in November 2014.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Youssef|first1=Bassem|title=Revolution for Dummies|date=March 2017|publisher=Dey Street|isbn=0062446894|page=190}}</ref>
==Awards==
In 2013, Youssef was named one of the "[[Time 100|100 most influential people in the world]]"<ref>{{cite news|url=http://time100.time.com/2013/04/18/time-100/slide/bassem-youssef/|title=Bassem Youssef - TIME 100: The 100 Most Influential People in the World - TIME.com|work=TIME.com | date=18 April 2013}}</ref> by ''[[Time (magazine)|TIME]]'' magazine and one of [[Foreign Policy magazine]]'s 100 Leading Global Thinkers.
In November 2013, Youssef's role in the media was recognized by the Committee to Protect Journalists, which awarded him with the International Press Freedom Award, along with three other journalists.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cpj.org/awards/2013/bassem-youssef-egypt.php|title=Bassem Youssef, Egypt|work=cpj.org}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cpj.org/awards/2013/bassem-youssef-acceptance-speech.php|title=Bassem Youssef Acceptance Speech|work=cpj.org}}</ref>
In 2015, Youssef received an [[honorary degree]] and delivered the [[commencement address]] for the College of Online & Continuing Education at [[Southern New Hampshire University]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.snhu.edu/about-us/news-and-events/2015/05/snhu-graduates-celebrate-commencement-with-trio-of-speakers|title=SNHU Graduates Celebrate Commencement With Trio of Speakers|author=Boutselis, Pamme|publisher=Southern New Hampshire University|date=May 9, 2015|accessdate=July 11, 2017}}</ref>
''Al Bernameg'' was chosen by [[South by Southwest]], one of the largest international interactive festivals, as the first and most successful [[internet]] to [[TV]] conversion story in the [[Middle East]]. ''Al Bernameg''{{'}}s [[YouTube]] channel was the first channel in the [[MENA]] region to reach one million subscribers and was awarded the gold button trophy.
==Personal life== [[File:Dr. Bassem Youssef (graffiti; 2012-04-20).jpg|thumb|Bassem Youssef graffiti 2012]] Youssef lives in [[the Bay Area]] with his wife,<ref name="PRI">{{cite news|title=Egypt's "Daily Show"|url=http://pri.org/stories/2011-03-28/egypts-daily-show|date=28 March 2011|accessdate=9 January 2014|agency=PRI}}</ref> an [[Egyptians|Egyptian]]-[[Palestinian people|Palestinian]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2013/04/01/The-Nile-s-Jon-Stewart-Bassem-Youssef-s-mission-to-raise-voice-of-reason-.html|title=Egypt's "Most Wanted": the comedian who made fun of Mursi|agency=Al Arabiya|date=2 April 2013|accessdate=9 January 2014}}</ref> and their son and daughter.<ref name="PRI"/> He worked as a [[Cardiac surgeon|cardiothoracic surgeon]] when ''Al Bernameg'' was on hiatus. In his capacity as a doctor, he assisted wounded [[Tahrir Square]] protesters after the [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011#Timeline|Battle of the Camel]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Montasser|first=Farah|title=Revolutionary satire: Bassem Youssef speaks to Ahram Online|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/5/35/19963/Arts--Culture/Stage--Street/Revolutionary-satire-Bassem-Youssef-speaks-to-Ahra.aspx|publisher=Ahram Online|date=29 August 2011|accessdate=9 January 2014}}</ref> Youssef is a [[Muslim]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/bassem-youssef-of-al-bernameg-on-new-web-series-fusion-the-democracy-handbook/|title=The "Jon Stewart of Egypt" pokes fun at U.S. politics in "The Democracy Handbook"|date=7 July 2016|publisher=CBS News|accessdate=1 April 2017|quote=As a Muslim and Arab, Youssef aspires to bring new perspective for the American audience.}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Television in Egypt]] * [[CBC (Channel)]] * [[MBC Masr]] * [[ONTV (Egypt)]] * [[OTV (Channel)]] * [[Reem Maged]] * [[Yosri Fouda]]

{{Infobox ice hockey player | image = | alt = | caption = | image_size = 230px | position = [[Defenceman|Defence]] | shoots = Right | height_ft = 5 | height_in = 11 | weight_lb = 200 | played_for = '''[[National Hockey League|NHL]]'''
[[Montreal Canadiens]]
[[Hamilton Tigers]]
[[Toronto St. Pats]]
[[Toronto Maple Leafs]] | ntl_team = | birth_date = {{birth date|1894|2|9|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Penetanguishene]], [[Ontario]], Canada | death_date = {{death date and age|mf=yes|1942|9|21|1894|2|9}} | death_place = [[Georgian Bay]], Ontario, Canada | career_start = 1914 | career_end = 1927 | halloffame = | website = }} '''Bertram Orian "Pig Iron" Corbeau''' (February 9, 1894 – September 21, 1942) was a [[Canadians|Canadian]] professional [[ice hockey]] [[defenceman]] who played ten seasons in the [[National Hockey League]] for the [[Montreal Canadiens]], [[Hamilton Tigers]], [[Toronto St. Pats]] and [[Toronto Maple Leafs]]. He was a member of the Canadiens' first [[Stanley Cup]] championship team in 1916. His brother [[Con Corbeau|Con]] also played professional ice hockey. ==Playing career== Corbeau played junior hockey for the Penetang Hockey Club from 1910 until 1912, when he moved up to the Penetang intermediate team. Corbeau signed as a professional with the [[Halifax Crescents]] in 1913, playing one season before signing with the [[Montreal Canadiens]] in 1914. Corbeau would be a member of the Canadiens until October 1922 when he was traded to the [[Hamilton Tigers]] for cash. In December 1923, he became a member of the [[Toronto St. Pats]] as part of a trade. He stayed with the Toronto franchise and was one of the original [[Toronto Maple Leafs]] before being waived in October 1927. He then played two seasons in the minor [[Canadian Professional Hockey League]] with Toronto Ravinia and the [[London Panthers]] before retiring as a player. From 1928 to 1929 he coached the Panthers and then for a decade was an NHL referee. Corbeau then returned to coaching with the Atlantic City Sea Gulls of the [[Eastern Hockey League]] from 1939 to 1942. Corbeau finally left hockey and returned to Penetanguishene, where he lived and worked as a plant superintendent at the Midland Foundry and Machine Company (supporting Canada in [[World War II]]) until his death from a boating accident. Corbeau was the first player to play for both the Canadiens and the Maple Leafs. In the 1926–27 season, he became the first player to record 100 minutes in penalties in one season. He was posthumously inducted into the Penetanguishene Sports Hall of Fame in 1987. ==Awards and achievements== * [[1915–16 NHA season|1916]] [[Stanley Cup]] Champion ([[Montreal Canadiens|Montreal]]) * 1940-1941 United States National Championships Finals * 1987 Inducted into the Penetanguishene Sports Hall of Fame ==Death== Corbeau died as the result of a boating accident in [[Georgian Bay]]. During a party hosted by Corbeau aboard his boat, the boat struck a sand bar. Portholes on the sides of the boat were open and water entered the boat through them, sinking the boat within a matter of minutes. Of the 42 persons aboard, 25 died, including Corbeau.{{cite web |url=http://www.yathehabsrule.com/2009/09/bert-corbeau-was-tough-but-not-for.html |title=Bert Corbeau was tough, but not for the waters of Georgian Bay |publisher=yatheabsrule.com |accessdate=2009-09-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718140044/http://www.yathehabsrule.com/2009/09/bert-corbeau-was-tough-but-not-for.html |archivedate=2011-07-18 |df= }} ==Hockey card== A collectible hockey card featuring Corbeau from the 1923–24 season is one of the rarest cards in existence. Only a handful were made by a company that featured them in a contest. Contestants who collected a complete set of 40 cards were awarded a pair of skates. The Corbeau card was "short printed" in order to limit the number of winners.{{cite news |title='Holy Grail' of hockey cards among ultra-rare collection up for auction |first=Randy |last=Boswell |newspaper=The Montreal Gazette |publisher=Postmedia News |date=October 7, 2013 |url=http://www.montrealgazette.com/sports/Holy+Grail+hockey+card+collections+heading+auction+block/9007129/story.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131009224452/http://www.montrealgazette.com/sports/Holy%2BGrail%2Bhockey%2Bcard%2Bcollections%2Bheading%2Bauction%2Bblock/9007129/story.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=October 9, 2013 |df= }} ==Career statistics== {| border="0" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="0" style="text-align:center; width:50em;" |- style="background:#e0e0e0;" ! colspan="3" bgcolor="#ffffff" |   ! rowspan="99" bgcolor="#ffffff" |   ! colspan="5" | [[regular season|Regular season]] ! rowspan="99" bgcolor="#ffffff" |   ! colspan="5" | [[Playoffs]] |- style="background:#e0e0e0;" ! [[File:Bertram Park.jpg|thumbnail|Bertram Park by Yvonne Gregory, 1930s.]] [[File:Southern Rhodesia 4d stamp.jpg|thumbnail|Park provided the photograph of George VI on which this Southern Rhodesian stamp was based and for many other stamps and official documents.]] '''Bertram Charles Percival Park''', [[Officer of the Order of the British Empire|OBE]], (1883-1972) was a [[portrait photographer]] whose work included British and European royalty. Engravings of his photographs were widely used on British and British Commonwealth [[postage stamps]], currency, and other official documents in the 1930s. His theatrical portraits were the source for two paintings by [[Walter Sickert]]. With his wife [[Yvonne Gregory]], he also produced a number of photographic books of the female nude. He was an expert in the cultivation of the rose and the editor of ''The Rose Annual''.
==Early life== Bertram Charles Percival Park was born in [[Minster-in-Thanet|Minster]], Kent, England, in 1883 to Charles Percival Park and Katharine Mary Park.<ref name=club>[http://thecameraclub.co.uk/2012/09/bertram-park/ Bertram Park.] ''[[The Camera Club]]''. Retrieved 28 August 2015.</ref><ref>[http://search.findmypast.co.uk/record?id=r_884575942 England, Births & Baptisms 1538-1975 Transcription.] findmypast. Retrieved 6 January 2016. {{subscription required}}</ref> He initially worked in the family firm which made artist's materials.<ref name=npgpark>[http://www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/person/mp05646/bertram-park Bertram Park.], National Portrait Gallery. Retrieved 8 January 2016.</ref>
==Family== In 1916, Park married the photographer [[Yvonne Gregory]] (1889-1970) at Hampstead,<ref>[http://search.findmypast.co.uk/record?id=bmd%2fm%2f1916%2f4%2faz%2f000811%2f029 England & Wales marriages 1837-2008 Transcription.] findmypast.co.uk Retrieved 28 August 2015. {{subscription required}}</ref> and she became one of his principal models. They had a daughter, Hilary June Park, who was born in Hampstead in 1920.<ref>[http://sounds.bl.uk/Arts-literature-and-performance/Art-photography-and-architecture/021M-C0467X0063XX-0100V0 Mardall, June], ''National Life Story Collection: Architects' Lives'', Part 1 of 10. [[British Library]]. Retrieved 8 January 2016.</ref> Hilary, known as June, was an architect who married David Francis Rivers Bosanquet in 1941 and divorced him in 1947. Her second marriage was to the Finnish architect Cyril Mardall (1909-1994) in 1947.<ref>[http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/55126 "Mardall, Cyril Leonard Sjöström (1909–1994)"], Anne Pimlott Baker, ''[[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]]'', Oxford University Press. Online edition. Retrieved 8 January 2016. {{subscription required}}</ref>
==Photographic career== In 1910, Bertram Park was one of the founders of the London Salon of Photography. In 1919, with funding from the Egytologist [[Lord Carnarvon]], he established studios at 43 [[Dover Street]], London, with his wife Yvonne and the children's photographer [[Marcus Adams (photographer)|Marcus Adams]].<ref name=npgpark/> They shared darkroom staff and facilities and were known as the "Three Photographers".<ref>[http://www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/person/mp04999/marcus-adams?role=art Marcus Adams.] National Portrait Gallery. Retrieved 8 January 2016.</ref>
Park's work included British and European royalty<ref>[https://www.royalcollection.org.uk/exhibitions/marcus-adams-royal-photographer/royal-portraits-by-bertram-park Royal Portraits by Bertram Park.] Royal Collection Trust. Retrieved 28 August 2015.</ref> and in 1927 he was made an [[Member of the Order of the British Empire|MBE]].<ref name=gaz1927>''[https://www.thegazette.co.uk/Edinburgh/issue/14345/page/654 The Edinburgh Gazette]'', 7 June 1927, p. 654.</ref> In the [[1939 Birthday Honours]] he was made up to [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]].<ref name=gaz1939>[https://www.thegazette.co.uk/Edinburgh/issue/15605/page/511/data.pdf ''The Edinburgh Gazette''], 13 June 1939, p. 511.</ref> His images were widely used on British and British Commonwealth postage stamps, currency, and other official documents in the 1930s.<ref name=cross>"The Bertram Park legacy", Brian Livingstone, ''Cross Post'', Vol. 15, No. 2, Spring 2014, pp. 14-21.</ref>
Park and Gregory were also noted for their publicity photographs for theatrical productions. In 1924 they photographed the first English production of [[George Bernard Shaw]]'s ''[[Saint Joan (play)|Saint Joan]]'' starring [[Sybil Thorndike]].<ref name=arena/>
In 1932, [[Walter Sickert]] produced his portrait of the actress ''Miss Gwen Ffrangcon-Davies as Isabella of France'', ("''La Louve''"), directly from a Park photograph without taking any sittings with [[Gwen Ffrangcon-Davies|Ffrangcon-Davies]], although they were closely acquainted. The source was acknowledged by Sickert in an inscription on the painting.<ref name=tate/> Park's photograph was in black and white so Sickert was obliged to add colour to the painting, however, he used a restricted palette causing the critic [[Frank Rutter]] to describe the work as "practically a monochrome".<ref name="Rose">{{cite book|author=Rose, Martial.|title=Forever Juliet: The life and letters of Gwen Ffrancon-Davies, 1891-1992|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fIOoYGF9LrgC&pg=PA61|year=2003|publisher=Larks Press|location=Guist Bottom, Dereham|isbn=978-1-904006-12-1|page=61}}</ref> Sickert also greatly enlarged the proportions, resulting in a finished work of 245 x 92 cm. Unusually, the [[Tate Gallery]] acquired the painting the same year after a fund-raising campaign to buy it for the gallery led by the Tate's director, [[James Bolivar Manson]].<ref name=tate>[http://www.tate.org.uk/art/research-publications/camden-town-group/walter-richard-sickert-miss-gwen-ffrangcon-davies-as-isabella-of-france-r1139306# The Camden Town Group in Context. Walter Richard Sickert ''Miss Gwen Ffrangcon-Davies as Isabella of France'' 1932.] Tate Gallery. Retrieved 29 June 2016.</ref> Sickert joked that it was "only bought for the Tate because of Bertram Park. Another proof that honesty is the best policy".<ref name=daniels>[https://www.jstor.org/stable/20074376 "Newly Discovered Photographic Sources for Walter Sickert's Theatre Paintings of the 1930s"], Rebecca Daniels, ''The Burlington Magazine'', Vol. 148, No. 1237 (April 2006), pp. 272-276.</ref> [[File:Jessica Tandy and John Gielgud in Hamlet.jpg|thumb|Jessica Tandy and John Gielgud in Hamlet. Photograph by Bertram Park (1934, left) and painting by Walter Sickert (1935, right) (whereabouts unknown)]] In 1934, Park and Gregory produced publicity photographs for a production of ''Hamlet'' at the [[Noël Coward Theatre|New Theatre]], London, one of which was the basis for Walter Sickert's 1935 painting ''Jessica Tandy and John Gielgud in Hamlet''.<ref name=daniels/> In 1935 they photographed Gielgud's ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]'' in which Gielgud and [[Laurence Olivier]] exchanged the roles of Romeo and Mercutio.<ref name=arena/>
Park and Gregory's theatrical portraits form part of the [[University of Bristol|University of Bristol Theatre Collection]].<ref name=arena>[http://www.arenapal.com/cms/page/bertram-park-and-yvonne-gregory-theatre-collection/ The Bertram Park and Yvonne Gregory Archive.] ArenaPAL. Retrieved 29 June 2016.</ref>
Park also produced a number of photographic books featuring the female nude and supplied photographs to [[naturist]] publications.{{citation required|date=January 2016}} One of his models was the 1950s glamour model [[Pamela Green]].<ref>[http://pamela-green.com/bertram-park-1883-1972/ Pamela Green portrait by Bertram Park], Pamela Green.com. Retrieved February 4, 2017</ref>
==Police career== Outside photography, Park was a Commandant in the [[Metropolitan Special Constabulary]] and was noted as such in 1927 and 1939.<ref name=gaz1927/><ref name=gaz1939/>
==Roses== Park was an expert on the cultivation of the [[rose]] about which he wrote many books. He was the editor of ''[[The Rose Annual]]'' and in 1957 a review in the [[American Institute of Biological Sciences]] described his ''The Guide to Roses'', for which he also provided the photographs, as "the last word on roses".<ref>Reviewed Work: ''The Guide to Roses'' by Bertram Park. ''[[AIBS Bulletin]]'', Vol. 7, No. 1 (Jan., 1957), p. 39.</ref>
==Death and legacy== In later life, Park lived in [[Pinner]], Middlesex, in a house whose grounds he used as a setting for his photography. He died in Pinner in 1972,<ref name=club/> leaving an estate of £103,322 net.<ref>"Latest Wills", ''The Times'', 27 February 1973, p. 16.</ref> In 1984, his daughter June presented the [[The Postal Museum|National Post Museum]] with an album of 25 pages that Park had created in the late 1940s of his photographs and the stamps based upon them.<ref name=cross/>
==Selected publications==
===Photography=== *''Living sculpture: A record of expression in the human figure &c.'', [[Batsford (publisher)|Batsford]], London, 1926. (With Yvonne Gregory and [[G. Montague Ellwood]]) *''The beauty of the female form'', Routledge, London, 1934. (With Yvonne Gregory) *''Sun bathers: A companion volume to "The Beauty Of The Female Form": 48 photographic studies'', [[Routledge Taylor & Francis Group|Routledge]], London, 1935. (With Yvonne Gregory) *''Curves and contrast of the human figure'', Bodley Head, London, 1936. (With Yvonne Gregory) *''Eve in the sunlight'', [[Hutchinson (publisher)|Hutchinson]], 1937. (With Yvonne Gregory) *''A Study of sunlight and shadow on the female form for artists and art students '', [[Bodley Head]], London, 1939. (With Yvonne Gregory)
===Roses=== *''Collins guide to roses'', Collins, London, 1956. *''The world of roses'', [[Harrap]], 1962. *''Roses: The cultivation of the rose'', [[National Rose Society]], 1967. *''The rose annual''. Multiple editions. (Editor)
==See also== *[[Dorothy Wilding]]
== References == {{Reflist|2}}
==Further reading== *Interview with Bertram Park, "Photographing Royalty for Stamps", ''[[Stamp Collecting (magazine)|Stamp Collecting]]'', Vol. XLVIII, No. 20, 7 August 1937, pp. 654-656.
